RespTxt: Scientific and technological changes cause unemployment
QuestionTxt: Some people say that scientific and technological changes cause unemployment because people's jobs are replaced by machines. Others argue that, while some jobs may be lost in specific areas, scientific and technological changes increase the total number of jobs over the long run. Which view do you think is closer to the truth?
SurveyOrg: Cambridge Reports/Research International
StudyNote: Sample size is approximate.

QuestionTxt: In general, computers and factory automation will create more jobs than they will eliminate.  Do you strongly agree, agree, disagree, or strongly disagree?
SurveyOrg: Public Opinion Laboratory, Northern Illinois University
SourceDoc: Public Attitudes Towards and Understanding of Science and Technology Trend Survey
StudyNote: The principal investigators were Jon D. Miller and Linda Kimmel of Northwestern University.  Susan Carol Losh of Florida State University produced the cumulative trend data file from which these results came.

RespTxt: Larger pay increases/No guarantee of job security
QuestionTxt: As you probably know, some workers are faced with the possibility that their jobs may be eliminated because of automation or the increased purchase of foreign imports. They may be offered the option of obtaining greater job security in exchange for accepting a smaller pay increase. If you were offered the option, which would you choose: greater job security with a smaller pay increase, or a larger pay increase with no guarantee of job security?
SurveyOrg: Opinion Research Corporation

QuestionTxt: As you probably know, some workers are faced with the possibility that their jobs may be eliminated because of automation or the increased purchase of foreign imports. They may be offered the option of obtaining greater job security in exchange for accepting a smaller pay increase. If you were offered the option, which would you choose: greater job security with a smaller pay increase, or a larger pay increase with no guarantee of job security?
SurveyOrg: Opinion Research Corporation

QuestionTxt: How much blame for the loss of jobs in this country would you place on automation, computers and technology--a lot, some, or not much?
SurveyOrg: New York Times
StudyNote: A second survey of 503 graduates of the class of 1970 of Bucknell University was conducted Dec. 1-19, 1995 and included the same questions. Those results are available from the Roper Center.

QuestionTxt: In general, computers and factory automation will create more jobs than they will eliminate.  Do you strongly agree, agree, disagree, or strongly disagree?

QuestionTxt: Overall, do you think...automation of jobs through new technology in the workplace has done more to help or hurt American workers? (If Necessary:) Has this done more to help or hurt American workers?
SurveyOrg: Princeton Survey Research Associates International
SampleDesc: national adult with an oversample of ages 18-64
StudyNote: The sample included a national sample of 1182 plus an oversample of 821 respondents ages 18-64.  Results are weighted to be representative of a national adult population.

QuestionTxt: Have you heard of persons in your firm having their jobs replaced by computers, computerized equipment or other forms of automation in the past three years?
SubPopulation: Asked of those ages 25-62 employed full time who use a computer at work (75% of those ages 25-62 employed full time, 33% of sample)
SurveyOrg: National Opinion Research Center, University of Chicago
StudyNote: Part of a continuing series of social indicators conducted since 1972.  The weight WTSALL was used for the responses presented here.  The study includes a national cross section of 2023 cases which is used here.  Also available is a re-interview panel of 1536 from the 2006 GSS.

RespTxt: Has done more to help my job or career
QuestionTxt: (Thinking about your work life, has each of the following done more to help or hurt your job or career, or hasn't it made much of a difference for your job or career?)...Automation of jobs through new technology in the workplace
SubPopulation: Asked September 14-28 of those employed/unemployed and looking for work/discouraged worker
SurveyOrg: Abt SRBI
SurveySponsor: Pew Research Center for the People & the Press
SourceDoc: Pew Research Center's American Trends Panel Poll
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted August 8-21 and September 14-28, 2017. The American Trends Panel (ATP), created by Pew Research Center, is a nationally representative panel of randomly selected US adults recruited from landline and cellphone random-digit-dial surveys. Panelists participate via monthly self-administered web surveys. Panelists who do not have Internet access are provided with a tablet and wireless Internet connection. The panel is being managed by Abt Associates.

QuestionTxt: Overall, do you think the automation of jobs through new technology in the workplace has mostly helped American workers, has mostly hurt American workers, or has neither helped nor hurt them?...Helped a lot, helped a little, neither helped nor hurt, hurt a little, hurt a lot
SurveyOrg: AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research
StudyNote:
861 respondents were interviewed online, and 177 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
